_prev_prog_3.Description: The process includes 5 storage vessels located in close proximity to one another.  Each vessel can hold up to 40,000 pounds of material.  Vessels containing listed RMP chemicals are located in LPG storage areas 6-9.  The listed materials are used as feedstock for pilot plant R&D operations. These feedstocks are fed from LPG trailers to pilot plant processes by means of pipe at a variable rate of 1-300 lbs/hr. Process emissions are controlled by PSV's, rupture disks and a flare. All pilot plant processes are vented to the facility flare. PHA's for site R&D operations also include the LPG storage vessels.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
EPA RMP Executive Summary

Chemical Research & Licensing is committed to the protection of the occupational health and safety of the people in our workplace, the public and the environment.  We believe that all occupational illnesses, injuries and environmental incidents are preventable, and that their occurrence is unacceptable.  Chemical Research & Licensing's objective is to continuously improve our health, safety and environmental performance and become a recognized leader in our industry.  Chemical Research & Licensing operates under a Health, Safety, Security and Environmental Management System (HSSE MS) to define and mange risks at our facility and conducts operations in compliance with applicable laws and regulations.

In accordance with policy, Chemical Research & Licensing will:

* Operate its facilities in compliance will all applicable federal, state and local regulations.
* Consider Health, Safety and Environmental implications during product development, testing, processing and storage.
* Devote sufficient resources to be viewed as an industry leader in the area of Health, Safety, Security and Environmental (HSSE) performance.

Risk Management (i. e. identifying and managing hazards and potentially adverse effects of activities on people, the environment, assets or reputation) is a vital part of HSE management and is "the heart" of any HSSE MS.  It consists of four basic steps:
* Identification
* Assessment
* Provision of Controls
* Recovery Preparedness

The assessment of risks and hazards should include consideration of the full life cycle of an activity from beginning to end.  All of these steps should be documented.

Chemical Research & Licensing shall:
* Identify major HSE hazards and potentially adverse effects and assess the related risks which could arise from the Company's existing, or proposed new, activities (including acquisitions, divestment, abandonment or merger) and which could potentially impact:
* Health and safety of employees, contr

actors and the public.
* The environment including soil and groundwater contamination.
* The company's reputation, liability or profitability.
* Asset damage.
* Use risk assessment methodologies, including scenarios and consequence/probability ratings (Risk Assessment Matrix), which are appropriate for the hazard, effect and associated risk being considered.
* Apply as a function of the risk level, appropriate controls to prevent, or reduce likelihood of, occurrence and applies appropriate recovery measures to reduce the possible effects of the HSE risks.
* Assure that measures for risk control and recovery are adequate and clearly linked with related tasks/activities (competence/responsibility) that are assigned to specific individuals in the organization.
* Manage changes to facilities, processes, operations and other activities to assure that hazards, effects and risks are reassessed and that plans for HSE event prevention, control and recovery are updated accordingly.
* Apply Product Stewardship as part of a HSE Management process that manages hazards and effects during all phases of the life cycle of our products.

Chemical Research & Licensing is a piloting and research facility relating to the petro-chemical industry.  The product we create is technology.  This technology is related to refining processes that use catalysts to speed up production using less equipment.  Our SIC Code is 8731 (NAICS Code is 54171). 

Worst Case Scenario:
* Vapor cloud explosion
* Instantaneous failure of inner and outer tank walls simultaneously
* Failure of all active safety systems
* Worst-case weather conditions: stable, low wind speed
* Total release- entire vessel contents of 40,000 in 10 minutes
* Area impacted .3 miles (1,746 feet)

Alternative Release Scenario:
* Vapor Cloud Explosion
* Failure of a 2" loading hose
* Active and passive safety systems working
* Emergency shutdown system isolates release
* Most common weather conditions
* Release rate 31 pounds per minute
*

Total release time 15 minutes
* Area impacted .10 miles (582 feet)

Accident Prevention Measures:
* Storage vessels are high-pressure construction, pressure relieves to flare
* High flow shutoff valve on LPG trailer
* Emergency equipment shutdown procedures
* Remote valves to isolate and limit release
* Water fog for releases
* Regulatory guidelines for safe operation (OSHA Process safety and EPA RMP)
* Risk management
* Mechanical integrity
* Employee training
* Process hazard analysis
* Policies and procedures for safe operation of equipment

Emergency Response Systems:
* Mobile fire protection equipment consists portable 20 pound and wheeled 50 pound mobile fire extinguishers
* Water fog can be used to minimize the effect of releases by knocking down vapors and cool tanks
* Alarm systems will notify employees and neighboring facility of an emergency
* Trained emergency responders are able to isolate the point of release
* Communication link to off-site responders
* Information can be posted on the CAER line system to notify the public and neighboring facilities of the type of emergency and what action is to be taken, i.e., Shelter-in-Place.

Shelter-In-Place:
* Upon notification, Go inside immediately
* Shut all doors and windows
* Turn off AC/heaters to stop outside air from getting inside
* Turn on the radio and listen for instructions
* Stay off the phone

Chemical Research & Licensing has had no reportable releases of toxic or flammable substances in the past five years..

Emergency Response Program:

It is the policy of Chemical Research & Licensing (CR&L) to establish and maintain an effective emergency response plan on site.
The facility emergency alarm system consists of paging horns, fire alarms, and high and low gas detection alarms.  All alarms are audible and are either automatically activated or can be manually activated.  To manually activate the alarms you must depress the red "Alarm Activation" button for two seconds on the fire alarm panel.  An

"all clear" announcement will be made once any danger has passed.

The first priority following any incident must be the health and safety of all persons involved. The response will depend on the incident and the resources readily available, and may include the administration of first aid, fire suppression, evacuation, shutting off equipment and/or notifying the ambulance police or fire departments.  Once the situation is secured, additional assistance may be sought as required and notification procedures must be initiated.

As part of the RMP management process, continual training is provided to company employees directly affected by the RMP rule and best management and industrial practices will continue to drive safety.
